name: Typography
htmlBanner:
Typography

The key goal of our entire visual system is to present information as clearly as possible. Well-executed typography that works within the system creates harmony and balance.

Text Styles.html:
Text styles

The key goal of our entire visual system is to present information as clearly as possible. Well-executed typography that works within the system creates harmony and balance.

Overflow content

We cannot always determine how typographic content will be displayed in our products when viewed in different screens and formats. Text overflow techniques helps us control what happens when an element's text content is too big to fit into an area.

Truncation and progressive disclosure are techniques we employ to indicate that overflow content has been reduced due to restricted space.

These methods hide content that can be relevant to users so use with caution.

Truncation

The process of shortening text content is called text truncation. Truncation is typically used for text or links that exceed the size of their container. Text can be truncated at the start, middle or end of a string using an ellipsis (...).
The ellipsis must represent three or more characters. There should always be at least four characters of non-truncated text in a truncated string.
Truncated text must be accessible to the user on the UI.

Starting truncation

  • The important information is at the end of the text string.

....6798

...6798

Middle truncation

  • Shortens a phrase or text string where the start and end contain important information.

Image...v2.png

Image...v2.png

Ending truncation

  • Indicates that content has been cut off.

The sentence will truncate once it exceeds the container’s max-wi...

The sentence will truncate once it exceeds the container’s max-wi...

Use native tooltips to show the full text on hover. If the text is longer than the capacity of a tooltip, use a popover.

When to use truncation

Good use cases for truncation include:

  • Tabular data
  • Breadcrumbs and pagination
  • Long URL links and long item names
  • Paragraph of text (i.e. a description paragraph)
  • Lists, i.e. search results, to show a preview of the content

If a text content container is resizable, the truncated text should adjust accordingly.

When NOT to use truncation

Never use truncation by design on page headers, titles, labels, priority and critical messages, or notifications.

Avoid truncation directly before or after punctuation whenever possible as it is difficult to decipher whether the punctuation is part of the ellipsis or part of the name (for example, don't truncate “video1.workshop5” to “video1…”).

Wrapping & progressive disclosure

Wrapping enables the text to wrap onto another line if it is longer than the available screen width. Text that should not be truncated or cut off should be allowed to wrap. Adequate vertical space should be made available for potential wrapping.

When a significant amount of content cannot be displayed on screen at the same time, use truncation (ellipsis) and a UI control to reveal the rest of the text by expanding the area or navigating to another location.

When to use progressive disclosure

‘Show more’ is a good solution for:

  • Lists
  • Breadcrumbs and pagination
  • Long URL links and long item names
  • Paragraph of text (i.e. a description paragraph)

If a text content container is resizable, the truncated text should adjust accordingly.

Localization

When UI text is translated into other languages, the length of the text string changes. To ensure that the translated version of the component can adapt to the layout without breaking it, allow sufficient expansion space.

A rule of thumb for localization is to allow additional expansion space that is 1/3 the length of the text string in the English language.

Redaction

Redaction is the obscuring of part of a text for legal or security reasons. Webex products use two methods of redaction that replace the text content with placeholder content: asterisks and midline ellipses.

The redaction method used must ensure that the redacted content cannot be accessed in any way.

Midline ellipses

Midline ellipses are bulleted characters that replace the characters. This style is most commonly applied to password fields.

Asterisks

Asterisks replace the characters with asterisks.

This style is most commonly applied to sensitive information such as account numbers or credit card numbers.

Typography.html:
Harmonious composition

The Webex typographic system provides the means to present information and text content in ways that respect and support the user’s workflow, and is optimized for their environment.

Well-crafted typographic layout and styles create visual distinctions between elements of content.

Typeface

When it comes to in-product typography, we use native fonts when possible to ensure natural visual integration with platform environments.

We have done a deeper research and review for Inter typeface

Font styles

Appropriate use of pre-defined font styles found in Momentum ensures consistency across the portfolio.

Android and iOS libraries deviate from the following styling, and instead use native styles.

Note: The italic font style is not supported by Momentum as it is not representative of our design language - clear and focussed typography to support readability.

Head

Body

Font sizes

To meet the WCAG AA standard for typography, the minimum font size used generally in Webex UIs is 14px (or 10.5 points). The largest size is the display style of 40px.

For all body text styles and headers, sub-headers and highlights, a contrast ratio of 4.5:1 with the background is required.

Layout

Alignment

Content is generally left-aligned. Centering is usually applied only when display size or banner sizes are used, typically on signature screens.

Interactive text

Link text is styled with an underline and uses the blue text styles. Body text that is interactive but not a link is typically styled in semi-bold, which is also the text-style for button labels.
